channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: In Moscow, the Fighting Is a World Away
item.description: A detachment from the battle in Ukraine is exactly what President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia is counting on as he carries out a domestic strategy of shielding his people from hardships.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Nanna Heitmann
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times

item.title: Russia Is Buying North Korean Artillery, According to U.S. Intelligence
item.description: Moscow’s purchase of millions of shells and rockets from North Korea is a sign that global sanctions have hampered the Russian military’s supply lines.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Yuri Kochetkov/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Russian rockets fired during exercises this month. A shortage of artillery could be a sign of restricted supply lines for the Russian military.

item.title: As U.K. Prime Minister, Liz Truss Will Face Hard Times
item.description: Coming to power during the worst economic crisis since the Thatcher era, Liz Truss will need all her ideological dexterity — some call it opportunism — to succeed.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Hannah Mckay/Reuters
item.media:description: Liz Truss in London on Monday after it was announced she had won the contest to become Britain’s next prime minister. Colleagues speak of her nerve, drive and appetite for disruptive politics.

item.title: Judge Grants Trump’s Request for Special Master to Review Mar-a-Lago Documents
item.description: The ruling also effectively barred federal prosecutors from using key pieces of evidence as they continue to investigate whether Mr. Trump illegally retained national defense documents at his estate.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer, Glenn Thrush and Charlie Savage
item.media:credit: Hannah Beier for The New York Times
item.media:description: A federal judge said that a special master could evaluate the documents seized from former President Donald J. Trump’s estate.

item.title: ‘Deeply Problematic’: Experts Question Judge’s Intervention in Trump Inquiry
item.description: A ruling by a judge appointed by former President Donald J. Trump surprised specialists and could slow the documents investigation.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.media:credit: Steve Helber/Associated Press
item.media:description: Mar-a-Lago, former President Donald J. Trump’s residence and private club in Palm Beach, Fla.

item.title: Saskatchewan Stabbings Suspect Found Dead, Canada’s Police Say
item.description: The body of a man being sought by the authorities was found with wounds that were not believed to be self-inflicted. The killing of 10 people stunned the country.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen, Amber Bracken and Dan Bilefsky
item.media:credit: Amber Bracken for The New York Times
item.media:description: Two officers investigating a home on Monday in Weldon, Saskatchewan, where an older man who was believed to be a victim of the mass killing lived.

item.title: Climate Change Is Ravaging the Colorado River. There’s a Model to Avert the Worst.
item.description: Success in the Yakima River Basin in Washington holds lessons for the seven states at war over water in the American West.
item.dc:creator: Henry Fountain and Ruth Fremson

item.title: Biden Administration Releases Plan for $50 Billion Investment in Chips
item.description: The Department of Commerce issued guidelines for companies angling to receive federal funding aimed at bolstering the domestic semiconductor industry.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Commerce Department has said its goal is to encourage the production of leading-edge semiconductors and shore up the supply of chips currently in use.

item.title: Rafael Nadal Defeated at U.S. Open by an American, Frances Tiafoe
item.description: The next generation of top American players has struggled heavily against Nadal, Novak Djokovic and Roger Federer in Grand Slams. Tiafoe broke through by winning 6-4, 4-6, 6-4, 6-3.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Futterman
item.media:credit: Julia Nikhinson/Associated Press
item.media:description: Frances Tiafoe celebrates after winning a point against Rafael Nadal.

item.title: Of Barbecues and Men: A Summer Storm Brews Over Virility in France
item.description: A Green politician told men to get over meat and masculinity for the sake of the planet, setting off a sizzling argument.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: Benoit Tessier/Reuters
item.media:description: Sandrine Rousseau, a member of parliament from the Greens, has thrust barbecue to the center of French debate.

item.title: Typhoon Live Updates: South Korea Dodges Major Destruction From Hinnamnor
item.description: The worst of the storm had passed, leaving severe, if isolated, flooding and damage in its wake. At least two people were killed and 10 were missing.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Road and farms under water in Gyeongju city on Tuesday.

item.title: Scenes from the Aftermath of Typhoon Hinnamnor
item.description: The storm swept past South Korea’s southeastern corner, causing at least two deaths, sparking a fire at a steel plant and leaving tens of thousands without power.
item.dc:creator: Chang W. Lee and Victoria Kim
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Flooding in Gyeongju, South Korea, on Tuesday in the wake of Typhoon Hinnamnor.

item.title: Zach Sang, the Ryan Seacrest of the Youth, Wants to Save Radio
item.description: The former syndication star and top-flight interviewer is rebuilding his daily show on Amazon’s new app, Amp.
item.dc:creator: Jon Caramanica
item.media:credit: Maggie Shannon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sang is an uncommonly gifted interviewer. He treats interview subjects not as famous people, but rather people who happen to be famous.

item.title: Liz Truss, Britain’s Next Prime Minister, Is Still in Thrall to the Empire
item.description: Liz Truss is absorbed in imperial thinking.
item.dc:creator: Kojo Koram
item.media:credit: Henry Nicholls/Reuters
item.media:description: Liz Truss, Britain’s incoming prime minister.

item.title: Has Bidenomics Been Good for Workers?
item.description: Yes, creating millions of jobs is a good thing.
item.dc:creator: Paul Krugman
item.media:credit: Maria Contreras Coll for The New York Times

item.title: Abortion and Trump Are Giving Democrats a Shot
item.description: This may be a year when politics gets flipped on its head.
item.dc:creator: Michelle Cottle
item.media:credit: Mark Peterson for The New York Times

item.title: Jonathan Pie on Liz Truss, Britain’s Next Prime Minister
item.description: With Liz Truss as its next prime minister, Britain is about to get a second helping of the policies that created its current crisis.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Pie and Adam Westbrook

item.title: Work Is Intrinsically Good. Or Maybe It’s Not?
item.description: A question to ponder on Labor Day.
item.dc:creator: Peter Coy
item.media:credit: Illustration by Sam Whitney/The New York Times; images by CSA Images via Getty

item.title: Education in America: School Is for Everyone
item.description: Our democracy sprouts in the nursery of public schools — where students grapple, together, with our messy history and learn to negotiate differences.
item.dc:creator: Anya Kamenetz
item.media:credit: Illustration by Chloe Scheffe; photographs by Internet Archive; Ansel Adams, Esther Bubley, Warren K. Leffler and Russell Lee, via Library of Congress; Museums Victoria, Muhammad Haikal Sjurki, Note Thanun and New York Public Library, via Unsplash; and Mikus, via Wikimedia Commons

item.title: Student Journalists Reveal a Changing World. Let Them.
item.description: The shutdown of a high school newspaper in Nebraska is only the latest episode in efforts to censor student publications across red states.
item.dc:creator: Margaret Renkl

item.title: What’s Behind the Pileup of Sex Abuse Scandals?
item.description: Sociologists see a pattern that goes beyond the culture of specific schools, churches and industries: an ingrained resistance to self-policing or defying a community’s hierarchy.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.category: Mormons (Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints)
item.media:credit: Rick Bowmer/Associated Press
item.media:description: The Temple of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints in Salt Lake City, Utah.

item.title: David Sedaris’s Diaries
item.description: The essayist talks about his book “Theft by Finding,” a selection of diary entries spanning 25 years that helped him find and shape his voice as a writer.

item.title: Good Things to Make With Summer Corn
item.description: Raw, stir-fried, grilled and puréed — there’s a corn recipe for every mood.
item.dc:creator: Tejal Rao
item.media:credit: Andrew Scrivani for The New York Times

item.title: Money to Burn: Lessons From the Premier League’s Transfer Window
item.description: English teams awash in cash broke records for players and prices this summer, proving again that they operate on a plane apart from their rivals.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith
item.media:credit: David Klein/Reuters
item.media:description: Sign the stars, sell the shirts, repeat.

item.title: California’s Heat Wave Sets Records, and Stretches Power Grid
item.description: Demand was expected to outstrip energy supply on Monday evening, an official said, and Tuesday could see record demand for power.
item.dc:creator: Michael Powell and Shawn Hubler
item.media:credit: Frederic J. Brown/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Several cities in California have opened cooling centers because of the heat wave. People escaped triple-digit temperatures on Friday at a center in Los Angeles.

item.title: Moon Landrieu Dies at 92; New Orleans Mayor Championed Integration
item.description: He rose in local politics in the 1960s and ’70s by nurturing crosscultural connections, even as many other Southern leaders of his era exploited racial division.
item.dc:creator: William Yardley
item.media:credit: Associated Press
item.media:description: Moon Landrieu at the White House in 1975. He won the mayor’s office in New Orleans in 1970 with a rare coalition of white and Black supporters.

item.title: Aaron Judge Hits 54th Home Run, Staying Ahead of Roger Maris
item.description: Judge’s go-ahead homer against the Twins has him on pace for 64 this season. He says he just wants to win. “It’s not all about me, no matter what happens.”
item.dc:creator: Tyler Kepner
item.media:credit: Noah K. Murray/Associated Press
item.media:description: Aaron Judge went 2 for 3 with a double and a two-run homer in the Yankees’ 5-2 win over the Minnesota Twins on Monday.

item.title: West Indian Parade Returns After Two-Year Covid Hiatus
item.description: Scenes from the Labor Day tradition, which returned to Brooklyn after it had been canceled for two years because of Covid-19.
item.dc:creator: Brian Josephs
item.media:credit: Stephanie Keith for The New York Times
item.media:description: At this year’s J’Ouvert — a french word that translates to “daybreak” — floats began their trip from East Flatbush to Grand Army Plaza, the festival’s start route, soon after midnight.

item.title: How to Cope With Fall Anxiety
item.description: As the most carefree weeks of the year draw to a close, pay close attention to your emotions. They might be telling you something useful.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer
item.media:credit: Guillem Casasus

item.title: The Secret to Raising a Resilient Kid
item.description: The ability to bounce back is more important now than ever; here’s how to impart it
item.dc:creator: Erik Vance
item.media:credit: Joao Fazenda

item.title: What to Know About the New Covid Booster Shots
item.description: New shots targeting the latest version of the Omicron variant will be available soon. When should you get yours? Here’s what experts recommend.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum
item.media:credit: Charity Rachelle for The New York Times
item.media:description: The new shots target the Omicron subvariant BA.5, the dominant version of the virus.

item.title: George Clooney and Julia Roberts on ‘Ticket to Paradise’
item.description: For their latest big-screen partnership, they play exes who take shots at each other. It’s not such a stretch to the fond insults they sling in real life.
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan
